transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your Positive Data Log. Can you share some examples of when you prioritized your own needs and the positive outcomes that followed?

Patient: Well, last week, I decided to take a day off from helping my sister with her kids, even though she really wanted me to babysit. Instead, I stayed home and worked on a music composition that I've been putting off for a while. It felt really good to focus on my own passion, and I actually made some progress on the piece.

Therapist: That's a great example, Jamie! You asserted your own needs by taking a day for yourself and engaging in an activity that brings you joy and fulfillment. How did it feel to set that boundary with your sister?

Patient: It was definitely uncomfortable at first. I felt guilty for saying no, and I worried that my sister would be upset with me. But after I explained why I needed the time for myself, she actually understood. It made me realize that setting boundaries doesn't always lead to the negative consequences I fear.

Therapist: That's an important insight, Jamie. Challenging those negative predictions and seeing that setting boundaries can lead to positive outcomes is a crucial part of this process. Let's look at your thought records now. Can you walk me through an example of how you challenged the belief that you must always put others' needs before your own?

Patient: Sure. The other day, my friend asked me to help them move on the same day I had planned to attend a music workshop. My initial thought was, "I have to help my friend because that's what a good person would do, even if it means sacrificing my own plans." But then I challenged that thought by asking myself, "Is it really true that a good person always puts others' needs first? Can I be a good friend while also prioritizing my own growth and well-being?"

Therapist: That's a great example of using Socratic questioning to challenge your automatic thoughts, Jamie. What was the outcome of that situation?

Patient: I ended up explaining to my friend that I had already committed to the workshop and that it was important for my personal growth. I offered to help them move on a different day instead. My friend was understanding, and I felt empowered by asserting my own needs while still being a supportive friend.

Therapist: That's wonderful, Jamie! You're making great progress in challenging those long-held beliefs and setting boundaries in a healthy way. Remember, it's not about completely disregarding others' needs, but rather finding a balance that allows you to prioritize your own well-being too.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. It feels good to see some progress, even if it's challenging at times.

Therapist: I'm proud of the work you're doing, Jamie. As we continue to practice these skills, it will become easier to assert your needs and challenge those negative beliefs. Remember, you are worthy of love and acceptance, even when you prioritize your own needs sometimes.
